it's a pain, yes: you can add Option "TouchpadOff" 2 to /etc/X11/xorg.conf under the Synaptics Touchpad section, that will turn off all scrolling.
man synaptics has a whole bunch of things you can adjust, I just used that as a hammer on that problem
there's some info on turning on SHMConfig (sp?) and then you can interactively change the stuff (ie, experiment)
add Option "SHMConfig" "On" to the synaptics section of /etc/X11/xorg.cof
then you'll need to log out, hit ctl-alt-backspace and log back in (may be overkill, but it works every time)
gksudo gedit /etc/X11/Xorg.conf; but first do cp /etc/X11/xorg.conf to the Desktop
backup before editing, always :)
